What we talk about when we ...

... talk about Want

Below are concise summaries of the anonymous letters in Want, Gillian Anderson's collection, organized as they appear in the book.

These summaries were created using Claude 3.7 Sonnet, Anthropic's large language model. The prompt used appears at the end.

Though created on a whim, this reference may be valuable for book clubs discussing Want. It offers a quick way to recall and locate specific letters throughout the collection.

Learn more about Want from Bloomsbury Publishing. Consider supporting your local independent bookstore with a purchase.

Technical details for this project can be found on GitHub.

Letters

  1. On Fantasies
  2. Rough and Ready
  3. To Be Worshipped
  4. Off Limits
  5. The Captive
  6. Kink
  7. Strangers
  8. Power and Submission
  9. Exploration
  10. More, More, More
  11. The Watchers and the Watched
  12. I Always Have A Thing For...
  13. Gently, Gently

1. On Fantasies

1. I long for someone I can trust completely to both dominate me and cherish me, to push my limits in private intimacy where I can surrender to desire without shame, exploring the contradiction of wanting to be both worshipped and roughly taken as music and passion fill my senses.
2. I yearn for a penis to experience the pleasure of making love to women with both tenderness and passion, yet my deeper fantasy is finding someone who truly desires, cherishes, and loves me—a genuine connection, even if fleeting.
3. 4. I'm happily married to my best friend, but I secretly fantasize about what my life would be if he died—whether I'd be brave enough to admit my desires, perhaps for women, and transform myself into someone new and courageous.
5. As I casually go about my day, I'm secretly immersed in vivid sexual fantasies—whether being taken from behind by a stranger, riding a British rocker while wine lingers on our lips, receiving oral pleasure from a serious politician, or indulging in a classic builder fantasy—all while appearing completely normal to the outside world.
6. My deepest fantasy is to be utterly desired and ravished by a partner who explores my body like a drug, making me feel uniquely arousing not just as another naked body, but specifically for who I am, igniting arousal through feeling intensely wanted.
7. In my sexual fantasies, I can imagine anything except myself, creating characters like "Harriet" to replace me, as the thought of being personally involved disgusts me, despite wanting to experience sex with someone who instinctively knows what I need and makes me feel safe enough to surrender control.
8. "I practise lucid dreaming. Every night I dream I have sex with the actor Pedro Pascal."
9. I fantasize about multitudes of cocks surrounding me: men riding other men, crowds masturbating around me, or myself as the centerpiece at a banquet with fat, old, rich men gawking with erect members of all sizes, all wanting to fuck me.
10. I fantasize about being dominated by a straight-looking older woman who uses me however she pleases, a desire that has been my sole path to orgasm since high school despite the guilt and shame I feel for not fantasizing about my husband instead.
11. While I cherish my beautiful marriage with its mature intimacy, I secretly yearn for both rough, anonymous encounters with unkind men who take me forcefully, and a passionate, all-consuming love with a wild, free woman whose touch awakens depths I never knew existed.
12. Despite my husband seeing me as vanilla, I secretly dream of being a famous porn star or sex symbol, both to overcome my body dysphoria as a trans woman and to be valued for my sexuality rather than just my intellect.
13. Since losing my husband of thirty-four years, I fantasize about our passionate sexual connection when I masturbate, while also finding temporary solace in infatuations with actors on screen during the long, lonely nights of widowhood.
14. 17. 18. 19. My most secret fantasy is of my boyfriend proposing to me in a legendary, mysterious setting—an experience I meditate on so intensely that I call it a "masturtation"—ending with passionate masturbation as the ultimate embodiment of this emotional desire.
20. 21. Having grown up with religious sexual guilt, I fantasize about uninhibited sexual freedom—making love in the dunes with the waves lapping at our feet, against trees in the forest, or backstage in costume between scenes—as an escape from my sexually mismatched marriage.

2. Rough and Ready

3. To Be Worshipped

1. My greatest sexual fantasy is to be worshipped as a divine goddess bathed in moonlight, with a partner who begs for my attention, praises me endlessly, and follows my every command while making love to me exactly as I desire, ensuring I remain the pinnacle of their desires long after we're done.

3. I dream of being worshipped by a masculine yet gentle man who secretly watches me undress, then skillfully pleasures my body with kisses and touch until I surrender completely to passionate, rough sex where I'm treasured yet dominated, culminating in intense mutual orgasms.
4. My fantasy is to be intensely desired by someone who craves me carnally and obscenely, who becomes wild with lust at the mere sight of my body—perhaps it's about feeling powerful, but the thought of being desperately wanted turns me on completely.
5. My deepest sexual fantasy is to be worshipped as a dominant goddess, commanding and controlling men who beg and submit to me completely, radiating power and sexuality that contradicts the submissive female role I was raised to embody.
6. As a lesbian with no attraction to men, I'm puzzled by my intense arousal at the thought of someone ejaculating inside me—not for procreation, but for the intoxicating feeling of bringing someone to such uncontrollable pleasure that they climax within me.
7. My sexual fantasy revolves around a caring, attentive man (either a past love or celebrity) who meets me by chance, makes me feel special and desired through genuine conversation and passionate intimacy, all without judgment or critique, culminating in tender affection that continues into the morning.
8. Despite being a lesbian with no attraction to men or penises, I find the idea of someone ejaculating inside me incredibly arousing—not for pregnancy, but because my body could bring someone to such overwhelming pleasure that they lose control.
9. I fantasize about a chance encounter with a man I'm strongly attracted to—someone who genuinely appreciates me, treats me with tenderness and respect, and makes me feel special through passionate, affirming sex where we're both completely present and equally enthusiastic.

4. Off Limits

1. I am consumed by desire for my best friend, fantasizing about touching and fucking her even during ordinary moments of my daily life.
2. I fantasize about intimate encounters with women, particularly unattainable actresses or characters from films and series, imagining their kisses, scents, and what might unfold between us in beautiful, dreamlike scenes that flood my mind.

5. 5. The Captive

1. 3. My fantasy involves being kidnapped by terrorists in a foreign country, where one of my captors—dangerous and violent—starts to touch me gently, leading to passionate, consensual sex that blends terror with intimacy, culminating in my eventual release and escape into a crowded street.
4. From childhood to my forties, my fantasies have remained consistent despite evolution—I am never in control, either injured and helpless or tied up and menaced, allowing me to experience taboo desires without needing to ask or consent, creating a freedom my real-life partnerships cannot provide.

</input>

1. Write the synthesis in the first person, as if you are the original author restating her fantasies as concisely as possible.

3. Capture the essence of the fantasy, including key themes, specific actions, settings, or participants that make the fantasy unique or particularly meaningful to the author.

5. Keep each synthesis concise, aiming for one sentence, or at most two short sentences, that encapsulate the core of what the author is communicating in her letter.

Be aware that two or more letters may have been accidentally combined. If you notice distinct demographic summary lines or clear topic shifts separating letters, treat them as separate letters, and *only in this case* then label each synthesis sequentially (a.), (b.), (c.), etc., together on a single line. Only add labels to your synthesized letters if there's clear evidence they are distinct submissions.
